abstract.text: A type that provides localized representations of measurements.
The width of the measurement unit.
The intended purpose of the formatted measurement.
The locale of the format style.
A type that provides localized representations of measurements.
Generates a locale-aware string representation of a measurement using the default measurement format style.
Generates a locale-aware string representation of a measurement using the provided measurement format style.
Specifies the width of the unit, determining the textual representation.
The visibility of the unit name of a temperature.
Modifies the measurement format style to use the specified locale.
The attributed style for the measurement format style.
Creates a string representation of a measurement.
Creates a list format style using the provided format style and list style.
Creates a list format style using the provided type and width.
Encodes the value into the specified encoder.
Creates a new instance by decoding from the specified decoder.
The type of data to format.
The type of the formatted data.
The hash value of the style format.
Hashes the essential components of the value by feeding them into the specified hasher.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether two values are unequal.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether two values are equal.
A type that provides localized representations of measurements with an attributed string.

The default format style in the previous example abbreviates the measurement unit. To customize any of the properties of the formatted measurement, you provide a measurement format style to the
method. For example, to create a string with the full name of the unit, the code might resemble the following:
The previous example uses a static factory method to create a measurement format style within the call to the
method. You can also create a measurement format style and pass it to the method, such as in the following example:
After you create an instance of a format style, you can use it to format measurements of the same unit type.
